name.description: The name of the aircraft, such as the such as the flight name or callsign.
name.caption: Name

speed.description: Ground speed of flight. This value is provided in meters per second with a minimum resolution of 0.25 m/s. Special Values: Invalid, No Value, or Unknown: 255 m/s.
speed.caption: Speed

location.description: The detailed geographical location usually associated with an IP address.
location.caption: Geo Location

uid.description: The primary identification identifier for an aircraft, such as the 24-bit International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) identifier of the aircraft, as 6 hex digits.
uid.caption: Unique ID

model.description: The model name of the aircraft or unmanned system.
model.caption: Model

serial_number.description: The serial number of the aircraft.
serial_number.caption: Serial Number

speed_accuracy.description: Provides quality/containment on horizontal ground speed. Measured in meters/second.
speed_accuracy.caption: Speed Accuracy

track_direction.description: Direction of flight expressed as a “True North-based” ground track angle. This value is provided in clockwise degrees with a minimum resolution of 1 degree. If aircraft is not moving horizontally, use the “Unknown” value
track_direction.caption: Track Direction

uid_alt.description: A secondary identification identifier for an aircraft, such as the 4-digit squawk (octal representation).
uid_alt.caption: Alternate ID

vertical_speed.description: Vertical speed upward relative to the WGS-84 datum, measured in meters per second. Special Values: Invalid, No Value, or Unknown: 63 m/s.
vertical_speed.caption: Vertical Speed

aircraft.name: aircraft
aircraft.description: The Aircraft object represents any aircraft or otherwise airborne asset such as an unmanned system, airplane, balloon, spacecraft, or otherwise. The Aircraft object is intended to normalized data captured or otherwise logged from active radar, passive radar, multi-spectral systems, or the Automatic Dependant Broadcast - Surveillance (ADS-B), and/or Mode S systems.
aircraft.caption: Aircraft

command_response.description: The reply to the request command (e.g. RESPONSE, BINDACK or FAULT).
command_response.caption: Command Response

opnum.description: An operation number used to identify a specific remote procedure call (RPC) method or a method in an interface.
opnum.caption: Opnum

rpc_interface.description: The RPC Interface object describes the details pertaining to the remote procedure call interface.
rpc_interface.caption: Remote Procedure Call Interface

dce_rpc.name: dce_rpc
dce_rpc.description: The DCE/RPC, or Distributed Computing Environment/Remote Procedure Call, object describes the remote procedure call system for distributed computing environments.
dce_rpc.caption: DCE/RPC

size.description: The size in bytes of the email, including attachments.
size.caption: Size

uid.description: The unique identifier of the email thread.
uid.caption: Email Thread UID

files.description: The files embedded or attached to the email.
files.caption: Files

from.description: The machine-readable email header From values, as defined by RFC 5322. For example example.user@usersdomain.com
from.caption: From

cc.description: The machine-readable email header Cc values, as defined by RFC 5322. For example example.user@usersdomain.com.
cc.caption: Cc

to.description: The machine-readable email header To values, as defined by RFC 5322. For example example.user@usersdomain.com
to.caption: To

subject.description: The email header Subject value, as defined by RFC 5322.
subject.caption: Subject

cc_mailboxes.description: The human-readable email header Cc Mailbox values. For example 'Example User <example.user@usersdomain.com>'.
cc_mailboxes.caption: Cc Mailboxes

data_classification.description: The Data Classification object includes information about data classification levels and data category types.

delivered_to.description: The machine-readable Delivered-To email header field. For example example.user@usersdomain.com
delivered_to.caption: Delivered To

delivered_to_list.description: The machine-readable Delivered-To email header values. For example example.user@usersdomain.com
delivered_to_list.caption: Delivered To

from_mailbox.description: The human-readable email header From Mailbox value. For example 'Example User <example.user@usersdomain.com>'.
from_mailbox.caption: From Mailbox

http_headers.description: Additional HTTP headers of an HTTP request or response.
http_headers.caption: HTTP Headers

message_uid.description: The email header Message-ID value, as defined by RFC 5322.
message_uid.caption: Message UID

reply_to.description: The machine-readable email header Reply-To values, as defined by RFC 5322. For example example.user@usersdomain.com
reply_to.caption: Reply To

reply_to_mailboxes.description: The human-readable email header Reply To Mailbox values. For example 'Example User <example.user@usersdomain.com>'.
reply_to_mailboxes.caption: Reply To Mailboxes

smtp_from.description: The value of the SMTP MAIL FROM command.
smtp_from.caption: SMTP From

smtp_to.description: The value of the SMTP envelope RCPT TO command.
smtp_to.caption: SMTP To

to_mailboxes.description: The human-readable email header To Mailbox values. For example 'Example User <example.user@usersdomain.com>'.
to_mailboxes.caption: To Mailboxes

urls.description: The URLs embedded in the email.
urls.caption: URLs

x_originating_ip.description: The X-Originating-IP header identifying the emails originating IP address(es).
x_originating_ip.caption: X-Originating-IP

email.name: email
email.description: The Email object describes the email metadata such as sender, recipients, and direction, and can include embedded URLs and files.
email.caption: Email

name.description: The name of the service.
name.caption: Name

uid.description: The unique identifier of the service.
uid.caption: Unique ID

labels.description: The list of labels associated with the service.
labels.caption: Labels

tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the service.
tags.caption: Tags

service.name: service
service.description: The Service object describes characteristics of a service, e.g. AWS EC2.
service.caption: Service

flags.description: The flags associated with the trace, used to indicate specific properties or behaviors, such as whether the trace is sampled or if it has special handling. Flags help control how traces are processed, logged, and analyzed, providing valuable context for tracing and observability tools in identifying trace characteristics or specific tracking requirements.
flags.caption: Flags

service.description: Identifies the service or component generating the trace, helping to track and correlate the flow of requests through various parts of a distributed system. This information is essential for understanding the role and performance of specific services within the broader context of system operations and for diagnosing issues across different components.
service.caption: Service

uid.description: The unique identifier of the trace used in distributed systems and microservices architecture to track and correlate requests across various components of an application.
uid.caption: Unique ID

span.description: Represents a single unit of work or operation within a distributed trace. A span typically tracks the execution of a request across a service, capturing important details such as the operation, timestamps, and status. Spans help break down the overall trace into smaller, manageable parts, enabling detailed analysis of the performance and behavior of specific operations within the system. They are crucial for understanding latency, dependencies, and bottlenecks in complex distributed systems.
span.caption: Span

start_time.description: The start timestamp of the trace, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. Like the end time, this timestamp is normalized across the trace system to ensure consistency, even when events are recorded across distributed services with unsynchronized clocks. Normalized time enables accurate trace duration calculations and helps observability tools track performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.
start_time.caption: Start Time

duration.description: The total time, in milliseconds, that the trace covers, calculated as the difference between start_time and end_time. This duration helps assess the overall performance of a request as it travels across various services, and is essential for identifying latency and potential bottlenecks within the distributed system. The trace duration may differ from individual span durations due to the propagation and processing times of the trace as it spans multiple components.
duration.caption: Duration Milliseconds

end_time.description: The end timestamp of the trace, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. Like the start time, this timestamp is normalized across the trace system to ensure consistency, even when events are recorded across distributed services with unsynchronized clocks. Normalized time allows for accurate trace duration calculations and helps observability tools track overall performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.
end_time.caption: End Time

start_time_dt.description: The start timestamp of the trace, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. Like the end time, this timestamp is normalized across the trace system to ensure consistency, even when events are recorded across distributed services with unsynchronized clocks. Normalized time enables accurate trace duration calculations and helps observability tools track performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.
start_time_dt.caption: Start Time

end_time_dt.description: The end timestamp of the trace, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. Like the start time, this timestamp is normalized across the trace system to ensure consistency, even when events are recorded across distributed services with unsynchronized clocks. Normalized time allows for accurate trace duration calculations and helps observability tools track overall performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.
end_time_dt.caption: End Time

trace.name: trace
trace.description: The trace object contains information about a distributed trace,  which is crucial for observability. Traces are made up of one or more spans, which are individual units of work in application activity. Traces track the journey of a request as it moves through various services in a system, capturing key details like timing, status, and dependencies at each step. Traces provide insights into system performance, helping to identify latency, bottlenecks, and issues in complex, distributed environments.
trace.caption: Trace

code.description: A numerical response status code providing details about the connection.
code.caption: Response Code

network_endpoint.description: Provides characteristics of the network endpoint.
network_endpoint.caption: Network Endpoint

endpoint_connection.name: endpoint_connection
endpoint_connection.description: The Endpoint Connection object contains information detailing a connection attempt to an endpoint.
endpoint_connection.caption: Endpoint Connection

location.caption: Geo Location

labels.description: The labels associated with the user. For example in AD this could be the userType, employeeType. For example: Member, Employee.
labels.caption: Labels

manager.description: The user's manager. This helps in understanding an org hierarchy. This should only ever be populated once in an event. I.e. there should not be a manager's manager in an event.
manager.caption: Manager

tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the user.
tags.caption: Tags

cost_center.description: The cost center associated with the user.
cost_center.caption: Cost Center

created_time.description: The timestamp when the user was created.
created_time.caption: Created Time

deleted_time.description: The timestamp when the user was deleted. In Active Directory (AD), when a user is deleted they are moved to a temporary container and then removed after 30 days. So, this field can be populated even after a user is deleted for the next 30 days.

email_addrs.description: A list of additional email addresses for the user.

employee_uid.description: The employee identifier assigned to the user by the organization.

given_name.description: The given or first name of the user.

hire_time.description: The timestamp when the user was or will be hired by the organization.

last_login_time.description: The last time when the user logged in.

ldap_cn.description: The LDAP and X.500 commonName attribute, typically the full name of the person. For example, John Doe.

ldap_dn.description: The X.500 Distinguished Name (DN) is a structured string that uniquely identifies an entry, such as a user, in an X.500 directory service For example, cn=John Doe,ou=People,dc=example,dc=com.
ldap_dn.caption: LDAP Distinguished Name

leave_time.description: The timestamp when the user left or will be leaving the organization.

modified_time.description: The timestamp when the user entry was last modified.
modified_time.caption: Modified Time

office_location.description: The primary office location associated with the user. This could be any string and isn't a specific address. For example, South East Virtual.
office_location.caption: Office Location

phone_number.description: The telephone number of the user. Corresponds to the LDAP Telephone-Number CN.
phone_number.caption: Telephone Number

surname.description: The last or family name for the user.
surname.caption: Surname

leave_time_dt.description: The timestamp when the user left or will be leaving the organization.
leave_time_dt.caption: Leave Time

deleted_time_dt.description: The timestamp when the user was deleted. In Active Directory (AD), when a user is deleted they are moved to a temporary container and then removed after 30 days. So, this field can be populated even after a user is deleted for the next 30 days.
deleted_time_dt.caption: Deleted Time

created_time_dt.description: The timestamp when the user was created.
created_time_dt.caption: Created Time

last_login_time_dt.description: The last time when the user logged in.
last_login_time_dt.caption: Last Login

session.description: The authenticated user or service session.
session.caption: Session

uid.description: The unique identifier of the connection.

boundary.description:
The boundary of the connection, normalized to the caption of 'boundary_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary(same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.
boundary.caption: Boundary

protocol_name.description: The IP protocol name in lowercase, as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA). For example: tcp or udp.
protocol_name.caption: Protocol Name

direction.description: The direction of the initiated connection, traffic, or email, normalized to the caption of the direction_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.
direction.caption: Direction

3.description: External network traffic between two endpoints on the Internet or outside the network.
3.caption: External

6.description: Through a virtual private gateway
6.caption: Virtual Private Gateway

1.description: Local network traffic on the same endpoint.

2.description: Internal network traffic between two endpoints inside network.

99.description: The boundary is not mapped. See the boundary attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

5.description: Through an Internet gateway or a gateway VPC endpoint

7.description: Through an intra-region VPC peering connection

8.description: Through an inter-region VPC peering connection

The normalized identifier of the boundary of the connection.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary (same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.
boundary_id.caption: Boundary ID

community_uid.description: The Community ID of the network connection.
community_uid.caption: Community ID

3.description: Lateral network connection. The connection was originated from inside the network, destined for services on the inside network.
3.caption: Lateral

1.description: Inbound network connection. The connection was originated from the Internet or outside network, destined for services on the inside network.

2.description: Outbound network connection. The connection was originated from inside the network, destined for services on the Internet or outside network.

99.description: The direction is not mapped. See the direction attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

direction_id.description: The normalized identifier of the direction of the initiated connection, traffic, or email.

flag_history.description: The Connection Flag History summarizes events in a network connection. For example flags ShAD representing SYN, SYN/ACK, ACK and Data exchange.

protocol_num.description: The IP protocol number, as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA). For example: 6 for TCP and 17 for UDP.

99.description: The protocol version is not mapped. See the protocol_ver attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

tcp_flags.description: The network connection TCP header flags (i.e., control bits).

name.description: The HTTP cookie name.
name.caption: Name

path.description: The path of the HTTP cookie.

secure.description: The cookie attribute to only send cookies to the server with an encrypted request over the HTTPS protocol.
secure.caption: Secure

http_only.description: A cookie attribute to make it inaccessible via JavaScript

expiration_time.description: The expiration time of the HTTP cookie.
expiration_time.caption: Expiration Time

is_http_only.description: This attribute prevents the cookie from being accessed via JavaScript.

is_secure.description: The cookie attribute indicates that cookies are sent to the server only when the request is encrypted using the HTTPS protocol.

samesite.description: The cookie attribute that lets servers specify whether/when cookies are sent with cross-site requests. Values are: Strict, Lax or None
samesite.caption: SameSite

expiration_time_dt.description: The expiration time of the HTTP cookie.

http_cookie.name: http_cookie
http_cookie.description: The HTTP Cookie object, also known as a web cookie or browser cookie, contains details and values pertaining to a small piece of data that a server sends to a user's web browser. This data is then stored by the browser and sent back to the server with subsequent requests, allowing the server to remember and track certain information about the user's browsing session or preferences.
http_cookie.caption: HTTP Cookie

name.description: The name of the Identity Provider.

scim.description: The System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM) resource object provides a structured set of attributes related to SCIM protocols used for identity provisioning and management across cloud-based platforms. It standardizes user and group provisioning details, enabling identity synchronization and lifecycle management with compatible Identity Providers (IdPs) and applications. SCIM is defined in RFC-7634

references.description: System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM) RFC.

scim.caption: SCIM

sso.description: The Single Sign-On (SSO) object provides a structure for normalizing SSO attributes, configuration, and/or settings from Identity Providers.
sso.caption: SSO

3.description: The Identity Provider is in a Deprecated state, or is otherwise disabled.
3.caption: Deprecated

0.description: The configuration state of the Identity Provider is unknown.
0.caption: Unknown

1.description: The Identity Provider is in an Active state, or otherwise enabled.
1.caption: Active

2.description: The Identity Provider is in a Suspended state.
2.caption: Suspended

tenant_uid.description: The tenant ID associated with the Identity Provider.

idp.name: idp
idp.description: The Identity Provider object contains detailed information about a provider responsible for creating, maintaining, and managing identity information while offering authentication services to applications. An Identity Provider (IdP) serves as a trusted authority that verifies the identity of users and issues authentication tokens or assertions to enable secure access to applications or services.
idp.caption: Identity Provider

name.description: The tactic name that is associated with the defensive technique. For example: Isolate.
name.caption: Name

uid.description: The unique identifier of the entity.
uid.caption: Unique ID

src_url.description: The versioned permalink of the defensive tactic. For example: https://d3fend.mitre.org/tactic/d3f:Isolate/.

d3f_tactic.name: d3f_tactic
d3f_tactic.description: The MITRE D3FEND™ Tactic object describes the tactic ID and/or name that is associated to an attack
d3f_tactic.caption: MITRE D3FEND™ Tactic

depth.description: The CVSS depth represents a depth of the equation used to calculate CVSS score.
depth.caption: CVSS Depth

severity.description:
The Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) Qualitative Severity Rating. A textual representation of the numeric score.

CVSS v2.0
  • Low (0.0 – 3.9)
  • Medium (4.0 – 6.9)
  • High (7.0 – 10.0)

CVSS v3.0
  • None (0.0)
  • Low (0.1 - 3.9)
  • Medium (4.0 - 6.9)
  • High (7.0 - 8.9)
  • Critical (9.0 - 10.0)
severity.caption: Severity

metrics.description: The Common Vulnerability Scoring System metrics. This attribute contains information on the CVE's impact. If the CVE has been analyzed, this attribute will contain any CVSSv2 or CVSSv3 information associated with the vulnerability. For example: { {"Access Vector", "Network"}, {"Access Complexity", "Low"}, ...}.
metrics.caption: Metrics

base_score.description: The CVSS base score. For example: 9.1.
base_score.caption: Base Score

overall_score.description: The CVSS overall score, impacted by base, temporal, and environmental metrics. For example: 9.1.

scim_user_schema.description: SCIM provides a resource type for user resources. The core schema for user is identified using the following schema URI: urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:core:2.0:User as defined in RFC-7634. his attribute will capture key-value pairs for the scheme implemented in a SCIM resource. This object is inclusive of both the basic and Enterprise User Schema Extension.

references.description: System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM) RFC spec.

scim_user_schema.caption: SCIM User Schema

scim.name: scim
scim.description: The System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM) Configuration object provides a structured set of attributes related to SCIM protocols used for identity provisioning and management across cloud-based platforms. It standardizes user and group provisioning details, enabling identity synchronization and lifecycle management with compatible Identity Providers (IdPs) and applications. SCIM is defined in RFC-7634

xattributes.description:
An unordered collection of zero or more name/value pairs where each pair represents a file or folder extended attribute.

For example: Windows alternate data stream attributes (ADS stream name, ADS size, etc.), user-defined or application-defined attributes, ACL, owner, primary group, etc. Examples from DCS:

  • ads_name
  • ads_size
  • dacl
  • owner
  • primary_group
  • link_name - name of the link associated to the file.
  • hard_link_count - the number of links that are associated to the file.

On macOS, binaries can optionally embed a copy of the application's Info.plist file which in turn contains the name of the executable.

4.description: Devices that verify identity-based on user's physical identifiers, such as fingerprint scanners or retina scanners.
4.caption: Biometric

5.description: Push notification is sent to user's registered device and requires the user to acknowledge.
5.caption: Push Notification

7.description: Application generates a one-time password (OTP) for use in authentication.
7.caption: OTP

8.description: A code or link is sent to a user's registered email address.
8.caption: Email

9.description: Typically involves a hardware token, which the user physically interacts with to authenticate.
9.caption: U2F

10.description: Web-based API that enables users to register devices as authentication factors.
10.caption: WebAuthn

11.description: The user enters a password that they have previously established.
11.caption: Password

factor_type_id.description: The normalized identifier for the authentication factor.
factor_type_id.caption: Factor Type ID

is_hotp.description: Whether the authentication factor is an HMAC-based One-time Password (HOTP).
is_hotp.caption: HMAC-based One-time Password (HOTP)

is_totp.description: Whether the authentication factor is a Time-based One-time Password (TOTP).
is_totp.caption: Time-based One-time Password (TOTP)

phone_number.description: The phone number used for a telephony-based authentication request.
phone_number.caption: Phone Number

provider.description: The name of provider for an authentication factor.
provider.caption: Provider

security_questions.description: The question(s) provided to user for a question-based authentication factor.
security_questions.caption: Security Questions

auth_factor.name: auth_factor
auth_factor.description: An Authentication Factor object describes a category of methods used for identity verification in an authentication attempt.
auth_factor.caption: Authentication Factor

uuid.description: The device manufacturer assigned universally unique hardware identifier. For example: The BIOS System UUID or the Apple IOPlatformUUID.
uuid.caption: UUID

bios_ver.description: The BIOS version. For example: LENOVO G5ETA2WW (2.62).
bios_ver.caption: BIOS Version

chassis.description: The chassis type describes the system enclosure or physical form factor. Such as the following examples for Windows Windows Chassis Types
chassis.caption: Chassis

cpu_architecture.description: The CPU architecture, normalized to the caption of the cpu_architecture_id value. In the case of Other, it is defined by the source.
cpu_architecture.caption: CPU Architecture

3.description: CPU uses the RISC-V ISA. For bitness, refer to cpu_bits.
3.caption: RISC-V

1.description: CPU uses the x86 ISA. For bitness, refer to cpu_bits.
1.caption: x86

2.description: CPU uses the ARM ISA. For bitness, refer to cpu_bits.
2.caption: ARM

99.description: The CPU architecture is not mapped. See the cpu_architecture attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

cpu_architecture_id.description: The normalized identifier of the CPU architecture.
cpu_architecture_id.caption: CPU Architecture ID

cpu_bits.description: The cpu architecture, the number of bits used for addressing in memory. For example: 32 or 64.
cpu_bits.caption: CPU Bits

cpu_cores.description: The number of processor cores in all installed processors. For Example: 42.
cpu_cores.caption: CPU Cores

cpu_count.description: The number of physical processors on a system. For example: 1.
cpu_count.caption: CPU Count

cpu_speed.description: The speed of the processor in Mhz. For Example: 4200.
cpu_speed.caption: Processor Speed

cpu_type.description: The processor type. For example: x86 Family 6 Model 37 Stepping 5.
cpu_type.caption: Processor Type

desktop_display.description: The desktop display affiliated with the event
desktop_display.caption: Desktop Display

ram_size.description: The total amount of installed RAM, in Megabytes. For example: 2048.
ram_size.caption: RAM Size

device_hw_info.name: device_hw_info
device_hw_info.description: The Device Hardware Information object contains details and specifications of the physical components that make up a device. This information provides an overview of the hardware capabilities, configuration, and characteristics of the device.
device_hw_info.caption: Device Hardware Info

type.description: The module type.
type.caption: Type

file.description: The module file object.
file.caption: File

base_address.description: The memory address where the module was loaded.
base_address.caption: Base Address

function_name.description: The entry-point function of the module. The system calls the entry-point function whenever a process or thread loads or unloads the module.
function_name.caption: Function Name

load_type.description: The load type, normalized to the caption of the load_type_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.
load_type.caption: Load Type

3.description: A raw module in process memory that is READWRITE_EXECUTE and had a thread started in its range.
3.caption: ShellCode

1.description: A normal module loaded by the normal windows loading mechanism i.e. LoadLibrary.
1.caption: Standard

2.description: A module loaded in a way avoidant of normal windows procedures. i.e. Bootstrapped Loading/Manual Dll Loading.
2.caption: Non Standard

99.description: The load type is not mapped. See the load_type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

4.description: A memory mapped file, typically created with CreatefileMapping/MapViewOfFile.
4.caption: Mapped

5.description: A module loaded in a non standard way. However, GetModuleFileName succeeds on this allocation.
5.caption: NonStandard Backed

load_type_id.description: The normalized identifier for how the module was loaded in memory.
load_type_id.caption: Load Type ID

start_address.description: The start address of the execution.
start_address.caption: Start Address

module.name: module
module.description: The Module object describes the load attributes of a module.
module.caption: Module

name.description: The schema extension name. For example: dev.
name.caption: Name

version.description: The schema extension version. For example: 1.0.0-alpha.2.
version.caption: Version

uid.description: The schema extension unique identifier. For example: 999.
uid.caption: Unique ID

extension.name: extension
extension.description: The OCSF Schema Extension object provides detailed information about the schema extension used to construct the event. The schema extensions are registered in the extensions.md file.
extension.caption: Schema Extension

algorithm.description: The hash algorithm used to create the digital fingerprint, normalized to the caption of algorithm_id. In the case of Other, it is defined by the event source.
algorithm.caption: Algorithm

3.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 2 producing a 256-bit (32-byte) hash value.
3.caption: SHA-256

6.description: The TLSH fuzzy hashing algorithm.
6.caption: TLSH

1.description: MD5 message-digest algorithm producing a 128-bit (16-byte) hash value.
1.caption: MD5

2.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 1 producing a 160-bit (20-byte) hash value.
2.caption: SHA-1

99.description: The algorithm is not mapped. See the algorithm attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

4.description: Secure Hash Algorithm 2 producing a 512-bit (64-byte) hash value.
4.caption: SHA-512

5.description: The ssdeep generated fuzzy checksum. Also known as Context Triggered Piecewise Hash (CTPH).
5.caption: CTPH

7.description: Microsoft simple non-cryptographic hash algorithm that works by XORing the bytes in a circular-shifting fashion.
7.caption: quickXorHash

algorithm_id.description: The identifier of the normalized hash algorithm, which was used to create the digital fingerprint.
algorithm_id.caption: Algorithm ID

fingerprint.name: fingerprint
fingerprint.description: The Fingerprint object provides detailed information about a digital fingerprint, which is a compact representation of data used to identify a longer piece of information, such as a public key or file content. It contains the algorithm and value of the fingerprint, enabling efficient and reliable identification of the associated data.
fingerprint.caption: Fingerprint

args.description: The arguments sent along with the HTTP request.
args.caption: HTTP Arguments

length.description: The length of the entire HTTP request, in number of bytes.
length.caption: Request Length

uid.description: The unique identifier of the http request.
uid.caption: Unique ID

url.description: The URL object that pertains to the request.
url.caption: URL

body_length.description: The actual length of the HTTP request body, in number of bytes, independent of a potentially existing Content-Length header.
body_length.caption: Request Body Length

user_agent.description: The request header that identifies the operating system and web browser.
user_agent.caption: HTTP User-Agent

http_headers.description: Additional HTTP headers of an HTTP request or response.
http_headers.caption: HTTP Headers

OPTIONS.description: The OPTIONS method describes the communication options for the target resource.
OPTIONS.caption: Options

GET.description: The GET method requests a representation of the specified resource. Requests using GET should only retrieve data.
GET.caption: Get

HEAD.description: The HEAD method asks for a response identical to a GET request, but without the response body.
HEAD.caption: Head

POST.description: The POST method submits an entity to the specified resource, often causing a change in state or side effects on the server.
POST.caption: Post

PUT.description: The PUT method replaces all current representations of the target resource with the request payload.
PUT.caption: Put

DELETE.description: The DELETE method deletes the specified resource.
DELETE.caption: Delete

TRACE.description: The TRACE method performs a message loop-back test along the path to the target resource.
TRACE.caption: Trace

CONNECT.description: The CONNECT method establishes a tunnel to the server identified by the target resource.
CONNECT.caption: Connect

http_method.description: The HTTP request method indicates the desired action to be performed for a given resource.
http_method.caption: HTTP Method

referrer.description: The request header that identifies the address of the previous web page, which is linked to the current web page or resource being requested.
referrer.caption: HTTP Referrer

x_forwarded_for.description: The X-Forwarded-For header identifying the originating IP address(es) of a client connecting to a web server through an HTTP proxy or a load balancer.
x_forwarded_for.caption: X-Forwarded-For

http_request.name: http_request
http_request.description: The HTTP Request object represents the attributes of a request made to a web server. It encapsulates the details and metadata associated with an HTTP request, including the request method, headers, URL, query parameters, body content, and other relevant information.
http_request.caption: HTTP Request

name.description: The name of the peripheral device.
name.caption: Name

class.description: The class of the peripheral device.
class.caption: Class

uid.description: The unique identifier of the peripheral device.
uid.caption: Unique ID

peripheral_device.name: peripheral_device
peripheral_device.description: The peripheral device object describes the identity, vendor and model of a peripheral device.
peripheral_device.caption: Peripheral Device

version.description: The version of the OCSF schema, using Semantic Versioning Specification (SemVer). For example: 1.0.0. Event consumers use the version to determine the available event attributes.
version.caption: Version

debug.description: Debug information about non-fatal issues with this OCSF event. Each issue is a line in this string array.
debug.caption: Debug Information

extension.description: The schema extension used to create the event.
extension.caption: Schema Extension

product.description: The product that reported the event.
product.caption: Product

uid.description: The logging system-assigned unique identifier of an event instance.
uid.caption: Event UID

extensions.description: The schema extensions used to create the event.
extensions.caption: Schema Extensions

labels.description: The list of labels attached to the event. For example: ["sample", "dev"]
labels.caption: Labels

log_level.description: The audit level at which an event was generated.
log_level.caption: Log Level

sequence.description: Sequence number of the event. The sequence number is a value available in some events, to make the exact ordering of events unambiguous, regardless of the event time precision.
sequence.caption: Sequence Number

tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the event.
tags.caption: Tags

profiles.description: The list of profiles used to create the event. Profiles should be referenced by their name attribute for core profiles, or extension/name for profiles from extensions.
profiles.caption: Profiles

correlation_uid.description: The unique identifier used to correlate events.
correlation_uid.caption: Correlation UID

data_classification.description: The Data Classification object includes information about data classification levels and data category types.
data_classification.caption: Data Classification

data_classifications.description: A list of Data Classification objects, that include information about data classification levels and data category types, indentified by a classifier.
data_classifications.caption: Data Classification

event_code.description: The Event ID, Code, or Name that the product uses to primarily identify the event.
event_code.caption: Event Code

log_name.description: The event log name. For example, syslog file name or Windows logging subsystem: Security.
log_name.caption: Log Name

log_provider.description: The logging provider or logging service that logged the event. For example, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing.
log_provider.caption: Log Provider

log_version.description: The event log schema version that specifies the format of the original event. For example syslog version or Cisco Log Schema Version.
log_version.caption: Log Version

logged_time.description:
The time when the logging system collected and logged the event.

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.
logged_time.caption: Logged Time

loggers.description: An array of Logger objects that describe the devices and logging products between the event source and its eventual destination. Note, this attribute can be used when there is a complex end-to-end path of event flow.
loggers.caption: Loggers

modified_time.description: The time when the event was last modified or enriched.
modified_time.caption: Modified Time

original_time.description: The original event time as reported by the event source. For example, the time in the original format from system event log such as Syslog on Unix/Linux and the System event file on Windows. Omit if event is generated instead of collected via logs.
original_time.caption: Original Time

processed_time.description: The event processed time, such as an ETL operation.
processed_time.caption: Processed Time

logged_time_dt.description:
The time when the logging system collected and logged the event.

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.
logged_time_dt.caption: Logged Time

modified_time_dt.description: The time when the event was last modified or enriched.
modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time

processed_time_dt.description: The event processed time, such as an ETL operation.
processed_time_dt.caption: Processed Time

metadata.name: metadata
metadata.description: The Metadata object describes the metadata associated with the event.
metadata.caption: Metadata

name.description: The operating system name.
name.caption: Name

type.description: The type of the operating system.
type.caption: Type

version.description: The version of the OS running on the device that originated the event. For example: "Windows 10", "OS X 10.7", or "iOS 9".
version.caption: Version

country.description:
The operating system country code, as defined by the ISO 3166-1 standard (Alpha-2 code).

Note: The two letter country code should be capitalized. For example: US or CA.
country.caption: Country

lang.description: The two letter lower case language codes, as defined by ISO 639-1. For example: en (English), de (German), or fr (French).
lang.caption: Language

99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

type_id.description: The type identifier of the operating system.
type_id.caption: Type ID

cpe_name.description: The Common Platform Enumeration (CPE) name as described by (NIST) For example: cpe:/a:apple:safari:16.2.
cpe_name.caption: The product CPE identifier

cpu_bits.description: The cpu architecture, the number of bits used for addressing in memory. For example: 32 or 64.
cpu_bits.caption: CPU Bits

edition.description: The operating system edition. For example: Professional.
edition.caption: OS Edition

kernel_release.description: The kernel release of the operating system. On Unix-based systems, this is determined from the uname -r command output, for example "5.15.0-122-generic".
kernel_release.caption: Kernel Release

sp_name.description: The name of the latest Service Pack.
sp_name.caption: OS Service Pack

sp_ver.description: The version number of the latest Service Pack.
sp_ver.caption: OS Service Pack Version

os.name: os
os.description: The Operating System (OS) object describes characteristics of an OS, such as Linux or Windows.
os.caption: Operating System (OS)

status.description: The resultant status of the classification job normalized to the caption of the status_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.
status.caption: Status

total.description: The total count of discovered entities, by the classification job.
total.caption: Total

uid.description: The unique identifier of the classification job.
uid.caption: Unique ID

category.description: The name of the data classification category that data matched into, e.g. Financial, Personal, Governmental, etc.
category.caption: Category

pattern_match.description: A text, binary, file name, or datastore that matched against a detection rule.
pattern_match.caption: Pattern Match

3.description: Any financially-related sensitive information or Cardholder Data (CHD). E.g., banking account numbers, credit card numbers, International Banking Account Numbers (IBAN), SWIFT codes, etc.
3.caption: Financial

6.description: Any sensitive security-related data such as passwords, passkeys, IP addresses, API keys, credentials and similar secrets. E.g., AWS Access Secret Key, SaaS API Keys, user passwords, database credentials, etc.
6.caption: Security

0.description: The type is not mapped. See the data_type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
0.caption: Unknown

1.description: Any Personally Identifiable Information (PII), Electronic Personal Health Information (ePHI), or similarly personal information. E.g., full name, home address, date of birth, etc.
1.caption: Personal

2.description: Any sensitive government identification number related to a person or other classified material. E.g., Passport numbers, driver license numbers, business identification, taxation identifiers, etc.
2.caption: Governmental

99.description: Any other type of data classification or a multi-variate classification made up of several other classification categories.
99.caption: Other

4.description: Any business-specific sensitive data such as intellectual property, trademarks, copyrights, human resource data, Board of Directors meeting minutes, and similar.
4.caption: Business

5.description: Any mission-specific sensitive data for military, law enforcement, or other government agencies such as specifically classified data, weapon systems information, or other planning data.
5.caption: Military and Law Enforcement

category_id.description: The normalized identifier of the data classification category.
category_id.caption: Category ID

classifier_details.description: Describes details about the classifier used for data classification.
classifier_details.caption: Classifier Details

confidentiality.description: The file content confidentiality, normalized to the confidentiality_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.
confidentiality.caption: Confidentiality

99.description: The confidentiality is not mapped. See the confidentiality attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

confidentiality_id.description: The normalized identifier of the file content confidentiality indicator.
confidentiality_id.caption: Confidentiality ID

data_lifecycle_state.description: The name of the stage or state that the data was in. E.g., Data-at-Rest, Data-in-Transit, etc.
data_lifecycle_state.caption: Data Lifecycle State

3.description: The data was being processed, accessed, or read by a system, making it active in memory or CPU. E.g., sensitive data in a Business Intelligence tool, ePHI being processed in an EHR application or a user viewing data stored in a spreadsheet or PDF.
3.caption: Data in-Use

0.description: The data lifecycle state is unknown.
0.caption: Unknown

1.description: The data was stored on physical or logical media and was not actively moving through the network nor was being processed. E.g., data stored in a database, PDF files in a file share, or EHR records in object storage.
1.caption: Data at-Rest

2.description: The data was actively moving through the network or from one physical or logical location to another. E.g., emails being send, data replication or Change Data Capture (CDC) streams, or sensitive data processed on an API.
2.caption: Data in-Transit

99.description: The data lifecycle state is not mapped. See the data_lifecycle_state attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

data_lifecycle_state_id.description: The stage or state that the data was in when it was assessed or scanned by a data security tool.
data_lifecycle_state_id.caption: Data Lifecycle State ID

detection_pattern.description: Specific pattern, algorithm, fingerprint, or model used for detection.
detection_pattern.caption: Detection Pattern

detection_system.description: The name of the type of data security tool or system that the finding, detection, or alert originated from. E.g., Endpoint, Secure Email Gateway, etc.
detection_system.caption: Detection System

3.description: A Mobile Device Management (MDM) or Enterprise Mobility Management (EMM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies on mobile devices (e.g., cellphones, tablets, End User Devices [EUDs]).
3.caption: Mobile Device Management

6.description: A Secure Email Gateway (SEG) is any tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies within email systems. E.g., Microsoft Defender for Office, Google Workspaces.
6.caption: Secure Email Gateway

0.description: The type is not mapped. See the detection_system attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
0.caption: Unknown

1.description: A dedicated agent or sensor installed on a device, either a dedicated data security tool or an Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies. E.g., Forcepoint DLP, Symantec DLP, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (MDE).
1.caption: Endpoint

2.description: A Data Loss Prevention (DLP) gateway that is positioned in-line of an information store such as a network share, a database, or otherwise that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies.
2.caption: DLP Gateway

99.description: Any other type of detection system or a multi-variate system made up of several other systems.
99.caption: Other

4.description: A tool that actively identifies and classifies sensitive data in digital media and information stores in accordance with a policy or automated functionality. E.g, Amazon Macie, Microsoft Purview.
4.caption: Data Discovery & Classification

5.description: A Secure Web Gateway (SWG) is any tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies at a network-edge such as within a proxy or firewall service.
5.caption: Secure Web Gateway

7.description: A Digital Rights Management (DRM) or a dedicated Information Rights Management (IRM) are tools which can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies on digital media via policy or user access rights.
7.caption: Digital Rights Management

8.description: A Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB) that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies in-line to cloud systems such as the public cloud or Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) tool. E.g., Forcepoint CASB, SkyHigh Security.
8.caption: Cloud Access Security Broker

9.description: A Database Activity Monitoring (DAM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies as part of a dedicated database or warehouse monitoring solution.
9.caption: Database Activity Monitoring

10.description: A built in Data Loss Prevention (DLP) or other data security capability within a tool or platform such as an Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) or Customer Relations Management (CRM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies.
10.caption: Application-Level DLP

11.description: Any Developer Security tool such as an Infrastructure-as-Code (IAC) security scanner, Secrets Detection, or Secure Software Development Lifecycle (SSDLC) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies. E.g., TruffleHog, GitGuardian, Git-Secrets.
11.caption: Developer Security

12.description: A Data Security Posture Management (DSPM) tool is a continuous monitoring and data discovery solution that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies for local and cloud environments. E.g., Cyera, Sentra, IBM Polar Security.
12.caption: Data Security Posture Management

detection_system_id.description: The type of data security tool or system that the finding, detection, or alert originated from.
detection_system_id.caption: Detection System ID

discovery_details.description: Details about the data discovered by classification job.
discovery_details.caption: Discovery Details

policy.description: Details about the policy that triggered the finding.
policy.caption: Policy

src_url.description: The source URL pointing towards the full classifcation job details.
src_url.caption: Source URL

status_details.description: The contextual description of the status, status_id value.
status_details.caption: Status Details

3.description: The classification job failed for the evaluated resource.
3.caption: Fail

1.description: The classification job completed for the evaluated resource.
1.caption: Complete

2.description: The classification job partially completed for the evaluated resource.
2.caption: Partial

99.description: The classification job type id is not mapped.
99.caption: Other

status_id.description: The normalized status identifier of the classification job.
status_id.caption: Status ID

data_security.name: data_security
data_security.description: The Data Security object describes the characteristics, techniques and content of a Data Loss Prevention (DLP), Data Loss Detection (DLD), Data Classification, or similar tools' finding, alert, or detection mechanism(s).
data_security.caption: Data Security

message.description: The message in a span (often refered to as a span event) serves as a way to record significant moments or occurrences during the span's lifecycle. This content typically manifests as log entries, annotations, or semi-structured events as a string, providing additional granularity and context about what happens at specific points during the execution of an operation.
message.caption: Message

service.description: Identifies the service or component that generates the span, helping trace its path through the distributed system.
service.caption: Service

uid.description: The unique identifier for the span, used in distributed systems and microservices architectures to track and correlate requests across different components of an application. It enables tracing the flow of a request through various services.
uid.caption: Unique ID

operation.description: Describes an action performed in a span, such as API requests, database queries, or computations.
operation.caption: Operation

start_time.description: The start timestamp of the span, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. This timestamp is normalized across the observability system, ensuring consistency even when events occur across distributed services with potentially unsynchronized clocks. By using normalized time, observability tools can provide accurate, uniform measurements of operation performance and latency, regardless of where or when the events actually occur.
start_time.caption: Start Time

duration.description: The total time, in milliseconds, that the span represents, calculated as the difference between start_time and end_time. It reflects the operation's performance and latency, independent of event timestamps, and accounts for normalized times used by observability tools to ensure consistency across distributed systems.
duration.caption: Duration Milliseconds

end_time.description: The end timestamp of the span, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. Like the start time, this timestamp is normalized across the observability system to ensure consistency, even when events are recorded across distributed services with unsynchronized clocks. Normalized time allows for accurate duration calculations and helps observability tools track performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.
end_time.caption: End Time

start_time_dt.description: The start timestamp of the span, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. This timestamp is normalized across the observability system, ensuring consistency even when events occur across distributed services with potentially unsynchronized clocks. By using normalized time, observability tools can provide accurate, uniform measurements of operation performance and latency, regardless of where or when the events actually occur.
start_time_dt.caption: Start Time

end_time_dt.description: The end timestamp of the span, essential for identifying latency and performance bottlenecks. Like the start time, this timestamp is normalized across the observability system to ensure consistency, even when events are recorded across distributed services with unsynchronized clocks. Normalized time allows for accurate duration calculations and helps observability tools track performance across services, regardless of the individual system time settings.
end_time_dt.caption: End Time

parent_uid.description: The ID of the parent span for this span object, establishing its relationship in the trace hierarchy.
parent_uid.caption: Parent Unique ID

status_code.description: Indicates the outcome of the operation in the span, such as success, failure, or error. Issues in a span typically refer to problems such as failed operations, timeouts, service unavailability, or errors in processing that can negatively impact the performance or reliability of the system. Tracking the `status_code` helps pinpoint these issues, enabling quicker identification and resolution of system inefficiencies or faults.
status_code.caption: Status Code

span.name: span
span.description: Represents a single unit of work or operation within a distributed trace. A span typically tracks the execution of a request across a service, capturing important details such as the operation, timestamps, and status. Spans help break down the overall trace into smaller, manageable parts, enabling detailed analysis of the performance and behavior of specific operations within the system. They are crucial for understanding latency, dependencies, and bottlenecks in complex distributed systems.
span.caption: Span

name.description: The name of the metric.
name.caption: Name

metric.name: metric
metric.description: The Metric object defines a simple name/value pair entity for a metric.
metric.caption: Metric

flags.description: The list of DNS answer header flags.
flags.caption: DNS Header Flags

type.description: The type of data contained in this resource record. See RFC1035. For example: CNAME.
type.caption: Resource Record Type

ttl.description: The time interval that the resource record may be cached. Zero value means that the resource record can only be used for the transaction in progress, and should not be cached.
ttl.caption: TTL

class.description: The class of DNS data contained in this resource record. See RFC1035. For example: IN.
class.caption: Resource Record Class

99.description: The flag is not mapped. See the flags attribute, which contains a data source specific value.
99.caption: Other

flag_ids.description: The list of DNS answer header flag IDs.
flag_ids.caption: DNS Header Flags

packet_uid.description: The DNS packet identifier assigned by the program that generated the query. The identifier is copied to the response.
packet_uid.caption: Packet UID

rdata.description: The data describing the DNS resource. The meaning of this data depends on the type and class of the resource record.

These activities and possible actions are defined by the upstream system controlling the Agent and its intended purpose. For instance, an Agent can include Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR) agents, backup/disaster recovery sensors, Application Performance Monitoring or profiling sensors, and similar software.

record_index_in_array.description: The index of the record in the array of records, where the information was discovered. e.g. the index of a record in an array of JSON records in a file.
